feature_type_description: Coherent sediment context within an excavation, without apriori description

A linear excavation feature. Although not structly a context bearing feature (as the trench is technically an absence of material) the term is sometimes used to label samples where no detailed contexts are given.
No feature description available
Upper covering of a structure. The bit that stops the rain getting in.

A depression interpreted as having been made by a larger, often wooden (but occasionally stone), object piercing the ground and subsequently filled with sediment. The term is commonly used to describe impressions left behind from fence posts or roof bearing posts and overlaps to an extent with stake hole.

A depression interpreted as having been made by a smaller, often wooden (but occasionally metal), object piercing the ground and subsequently filled with sediment. The term is commonly used to describe impressions left behind from fence posts or roof bearing posts and overlaps to an extent with post hole, but is less common.
A linear depression feature of unspecified size.
Defensive structure, e.g. wall, earthwork, tower, fort, castle, fortified house
Natural or man made hole or depression of unspecified type
Pit interpreted as having been used for the heating of food. Often used to loosly categorize pits showing evidence of heating.

Pit showing evidence of having contained standing water, often evidenced archaeological by horizontal organic layers at the bottom and collapsed steep sides. Sometimes intechangable with watering hole or dew pond.
Pit or structure used for waste products and/or refuse.
Longitudinal pit or structure suggesting or showing evidence of the transporation of liquids or other materials.
Strucural support for a building or other construction (such as a wall)
Gerneral term for cultural layers significantly darker in colour than surrounding sediments/layers.
Any human made construction of unspecified type.
Structure provided for the removal of water or water borne material for either waste disposal or drainage.
Pit interpreted as an animal trap
Structure interpreted as having an enclosed space designated for living or other activities.
Any constrained sedimentological unit
Layer representing a previously active ground surface.
General term for waste pit or refuse layers.
Transport surface layer.
Structure or composition of stones either marking a burial or of unknown purpose.
Structure marking a boundary of, for example, a building or field. Most often but not exclusively made of stone, brick, wattle and daub, dung or turf.
Fireplace
Layers formed by industrial activities of either known or unknown character, e.g. slag deposits, ash layers
Container for human remains, often made of wood, stone or lead and occasionally bark.
Layer defined as having originated through natural processes without the assistance of humans. Definition may be complicated by issues relating to the extent and influence of human actions.

Grave formed by a confined space containing the remains of one or more individuals. Structure often made of stone slabs as sides and roof (dolmen), either subterrainan, partially or fully above ground. Cist graves often are or have been covered by a barrow (earth mound). Term may refer to the whole grave or just the burial chamber.

A generic term used to describe an area separated from its surrounding by some form of boundary. The boundary may consist of an earthen mound (which in itself may be the remains of an earlier construction), stones, fences or walls, to name but a few.
A terrace like earthen bank features resulting from the long term ploughing across slopes.
Burial of undefined type
Single context term used to describe the material within a constrained excavation unit or cut feature.

A type of oven (thermally insulated chamber) for heating in the context of production or industry. E.g. brick kiln, pottery kiln. A large variety of types exist and there is some overlap in definitions between oven, kiln and furnace.
A thermally insulated chamber used for heating, most often used in the context of food preparation but may overlap with kiln or furnace by usage.

A type of oven (themally insulated chamber) used for heating in the context of household heating or industrial processes (e.g. metallrgy). Some overlap with kiln occurs and there is variation in usage between British and American English.

Any type of container for the storage or utilisation of products, especially food or drink. May also refer to containers used in industrial processes, such as smelting or for the storage of raw materials.

A layer of earth containing traces of human activity or habitation. Often represented by the inclusion of waste material (bone, wood etc.) and/or artefacts and anomolously high values for indicator elements (e.g. phosphates). The term is often used during excavation to describe layers considered of particular archaeological interest, and as such often an a-priori construct.
A structure interpreted as having been an excavation depression for the anchoring of a building's wall or for the placement of its foundations or posts. May or may not contain evidence of post holes.

Layer consisting of occupation material/debris or compacted sediments interpreted as the floor of a subterranian dwelling, storage building or building used for other cultural activities. The term sunken featured building floor is sometimes used as equivalent or so as to avoid the implication of habitation in the structure.
Feature type is either of a unknown character or not specified
Cage, cylinder or box filled with rocks, concrete or sometimes sand and soil for use in civil engineering, road building, military application and landscaping
A framework of timber or steel for support in marshy or treacherous soil
Deposits resulting from the roasting of ore.
Deposits of slag resulting from metal production.
A wall of a trench/test pit in an archaeological excavation, depicting the layers at the site and often sampled.
A site previously inhabited where worked objects, raw material, refuse and/or remains from buildings are left.

feature_type_name: Setlement site and iron production site

feature_type_description: A vague term which alludes to the site having a religous/ceremonial character.
A heap of stones that have cracked and weathered due to heating.
A cultural layer of a city character.
A collection of items intentionally deposited in the ground
Object found exposed in the surface layer without any connection to its original context.
Container that stores waste product.
Drainage system installed beneath the ground.
A fortified structure.
Structure supporting the ends of a bridge.
Barrier that restricts water flow.
Vessel used for tanning.
A flat surface of a room or area which you walk on, it may consist of compacted dirt or other material such as wood and stone.
Permanent covering of a floor in a building that makes up the walking surface.
One or a group of structures on or near a shire, used to handle boats or ships.
A structure made using plants and the wicker weaving method.
An area used to dock and unload people and cargo. Unspecified if it is for ships or boats.
Any kind of construction made out of logs.
Production of charcoal.
A distinctive style of building, with heavy timbers used as framing.
Room under the ground floor.
A defensive structure that forms a part of fortifications such as castles or defensive walls.
Container made out of different materials, e.g. wood or other plant material.
Also referred to as a "cut"; refers to the cutting away of a deposit or a structure. E.g. a cultural layer may be trunctuated by a pit constructed at a later point in time.
An archaeological test pit to survey for cultural remains.
A collection of piles deposited together
A depression designed to collect fluids, but not necessarily a street gutter.
A building type where sturdy posts are placed vertically for primary support, and planks are fitted horizontally to create walls.
Medieval wooden Christian church building that used to be common in north-western Europe. Built using the post-and-lintel construction method.
A place for ships to load and discharge cargo and passengers. This may encompass one or multiple wharves and loading areas.
Boat made from a hollowed-out tree. Also referred to as dugout canoe.
A support structure for buildings and constructions
Wood remains where it is difficult to discern its original purpose.
Surface constructed from individual bricks (made from clay) laid like tiles, with or without mortar or grouting.
Tar kilns are often constructed in a slope, with the outlet for the tar positioned below the kiln. Outlets were typically a hollow log, chute or similar.
Drainage system
Wooden water pipe
Materials that provide a bed, flat layer, for a structure or building. E.g. debris from demolished buildings used to form a base for a road.
A deep and wide trench surrounding a fortification.
A type of movable bridge used with fortifications and bridges.
